content.description: Starting on smooth crimps, yard up on a series of shallow but positive pockets. A very small left hand pocket and a meager crimp lead to a toss for the top edge finish. I like a small tick mark, pre-placed, on the final edge as it's sorta invisible.
content.location: On the left boulder of the Front Side Boulders. Starts a few feet left of Tiny Dancer.

content.description: Climb the thin slabby seam on the right end of the boulder.
content.location: On the right side (not the front or back) of Right Erratic boulder. Just right of the downclimb.

content.description: Start at shallow pockets and climb up to a decent right hand crimp. Traverse left (crux) into dueling two-fingers and fire off another boulder problem utilizing a glued edge to top out.
content.protection: Pads, spotter, pea gravel at base.
content.location: Second problem from the left side of Walter Weed boulder.

content.description: The first hard boulder problem in Austin remains respectable today.  A Bull Creek classic.  Reachy.
content.protection: Stack as many pads as you need.
content.location: On the right side of the left boulder.  The first problem after the big holds end.  Deadpoint to a three finger pocket and make another very long move to a dish.  Top out enjoyably.

content.description: On the backside of the Walter Weed boulder, sit-start and climb the obvious sickle-shaped flake on the left side.
content.location: Backside of Walter Weed boulder, left side

content.description: Begin in two dishes at shoulder height near the middle of left boulder.  Make hard moves through a series of monos to a sloping hueco and top out.
content.location: The middle of the left boulder.

content.description: Climb the good pockets up to the ledge and top out. Downclimb using the small boulder immediately to the right of this route. Be careful downclimbing, as the small boulder is quite polished and can be slick.
content.protection: Pads, spotter. Pea gravel at base of boulder.
content.location: Rightmost problem on Bill Boulder.

content.description: Climb straight up to the large hueco. Same finish as Dazzling Desperation.
content.protection: Pads, spotter. Pea gravel at base of boulder.
content.location: Fourth problem from the left of Bill Boulder.

content.description: Starts far left by the arete. Use pockets with the arete off or on (doesn't affect the grade) and then traverse right into the dueling two-fingers of Viagra and finish that route.

Screaming Fingers runs along the leftmost side of the right Frontside Boulders.  Follow big pockets and slick huecos to a slopey top out.  The crux is just trying to stick your feet on the greasy, polished face.
content.protection: A pad is a good idea (despite the pea gravel at the base) as this is one of the higher problems, falling  from which could lead to a nice banged up ankle or knee.
content.location: This is the left-most problem on the right Frontside Boulder.

content.description: Starting on the far left side of the frontside (Walter Reed) boulder, climb the arete using jugs, easy pockets, and solid slopers.
content.location: Stand start at the far left side of the "frontside / Walter Reed" boulder.  Down climb is located at the far right side of the frontside / Bill Boulder.

content.description:
Begins on the same two crimpers as Xanax but moves up and left. Hit the first pocket right-handed and then bust left through a small crimper and tweeky little two finger pocket. Make another move to a better pocket and top out.

 NOTE: this problem is graded as "V-impossible" in the Austin guidebook due to critical hold breakage.
content.location: On the left boulder, starts on the two crimpers to the left of Tiny Dancer.  Same start as Xanax.

content.description: Climb up good pockets on the right side of the left boulder and top out. Nice warmup.
content.location: Right side of the left boulder.

content.description: Aside from the potential need for pad stacking, this is an interesting little line with a few consistent moves. There is different beta depending on height it shouldn't alter the grade too much. I would also recommend scoping out the top before you get up there.There is also the potential to start with your left hand lower on this barely existent edge/thumb catch but it would add a few grades and make the line even more gross. Give it a go :-)
content.location: To the right of Hole in the Wall, start directly below where the seam meets the top of the boulder. Your left hand will be on a thin and slightly sharp hold on the seam about halfway up, and your right hand will be on a two-finger divet pocket. Go directly up to the somewhat awkward slopers and top out.

content.description: On the backside of the "Frontside" boulder to the far right(aka Walter Reed Boulder, backside), stand start and climb the arete using a series of pinches and sidepulls on polished holds.  Beware of the concrete landing area.  Crux is topping out.
content.location: On the backside of the frontside boulder, far right i.e. Rightside of the Walter Reed boulder, backside.

content.description: Pad stack makes this a little sad, but if you like short and simple boulders give this a try. Establish on the unfortunate starting holds, huck up to the decent hold and then shimmy over to the jug at the lip.Real potential for a sit start (maybe with just left hand in the low hueco, or even matched in in??) that would add 2-3 grades, but unfortunately impossible for shorter people. 5'6 might be the limit, depending on wingspan.
content.location: To the right of Pocket Sleuth, look for the hueco-looking hold about 3/4 of the way up the wall. Left hand start is an awkward shart point and right hand is a thin crimp. Padstack to get left foot up to the big foothold. Trend right to topout, there is a jug.

content.description: Eliminate problem starting between Screaming Fingers and Dazzling Desperation, sharing no holds with either. Climb straight up the mossy part of the wall on small pockets.
content.location: Second problem from the right on Bill Boulder.

content.description: Start with your right finger in a mono about 6' above the concrete slab. Dyno up to the only pocket available with the left and dyno again to the top. Have fun with the match and mantle topout.
content.location: Located on the back side of the Left Boulder, right in the middle. This area used to be a bathroom so there are a couple of drilled holes on the rockface formerly for plumbing.

content.description: Move from a left hand gaston and a right hand pocket through small pockets to a large pocket before topping out.
content.location: Route is to the right of Classic.

content.description: On the small right boulder (to the right of the Bill Boulder), Sit start the crack and finger jam your way up. Note that in Texas Limestone Bouldering (2011, Jeff Jackson) this route is called "Balanced Equation".
content.location: On the small boulder to the right of the Bill Boulder.

content.description: Stand start on the huge hueco and climb up the face on pockets and crimps, which are all left of the crescent shaped hold.
content.location: Centerline on the right frontside (Bill) boulder

content.description: On the Walter Weed Boulder, starting on the right side of the boulder, climb the left trending ramp using the jugs and pockets.
content.location: Right side of the Walter Weed boulder. Right of Walter Weed shuffle

content.description: Starts on a right hand sidepull/crimp. Set your feet where you can and dyno to the V-shaped notch directly above. Graded V4 in Texas Limestone Bouldering.
content.location: Backside boulder, one route to the right of Freaking Feet.

content.description: Stand start with your left hand on the two pockets and your right on a mono.  Move up the face on small pockets and positive crimps into a sharp mono.  Crank up to a good left pocket before topping out.   Crux is getting good foot positions and moving into the final pocket off the mono.
content.location: Off-center and to the left; just left of "Left of Classic."

content.description: Stand stand on the good side pull and crimp edge. Figure out how to move off the start with the good foot pocket out right and move up to the lip.
content.location: On the backside Boulder, leftmost climb.

content.description: Stand start with a right hand in good pocket and a left hand on a small sloper.  Move up onto another slopey crimp & mono into a left gaston/pocket.  ***Large hueco is off according to topo guide***  There are two good crimps to get your feet into position to move to slopey hueco and finish on good pocket just above.  Crux is the slabby feet.
content.location: Located centerline on the right frontside boulder (Bill Boulder).

content.description: Start with left hand in mono bolt hole, deadpoint to a right hand gaston, then to pocket below the lip.
content.location: Second problem from the right on backside of Walter Weed boulder.

content.description: Start at the two-finger sprag. Climb right to the large hueco then straight to the top.
content.protection: Pads, spotter. Pea gravel at base of boulder.
content.location: Third problem from the left of Bill Boulder.

content.description: The left boulder traverse.  Start on the ride side of the boulder with the toss on Walter Weed.  Work left through several monos and a series of difficult matches in two finger pockets.  Finish out Prescription Child to the upper left end of the boulder.
content.location: Front side of the left boulder

content.description: This problem is the chimney crack to the left of Underdog. Start with your back against the right side of the crack and make your way up using chimney technique and good feet until you can reach the crack where the two boulders converge. Here you will find bomb hand/fist jams which allow you to adjust your body position 180 degrees in order to  climb the second half of the problem in a chimney fashion and ultimately reach the hueco undercling that will help you top out to the left. The problem can be sent using minimal crack technique if you so desire, but I think employing chimney/jam techniques makes this problem a hell of a lot more fun!

Stand start on good pockets and continue to climb on good pockets to the right of the arch/crescent shaped-hold (just to the right and off-center of the boulder) up to the top.  Pockets are solid.  Near classic, easy slab climbing.
content.location: Route starts just off-center and to the right,just below the crescent shaped hold.

content.description: As the name implies, make some chimney moves to climb in between the two boulders. After moving up a bit, turn around and top out the Left Erratic boulder.
content.location: In between the two boulders on the front side.

content.description: Start on the pockets and climb straight to the top! Avoid using the curved ledge.
content.protection: Pads, spotter. Pea gravel at base of boulder.
content.location: Second problem from the right on Bill Boulder.

content.description: Traverse the entire Right Erratic boulder from right to left, staying at or below the level of the rock scar at the start of Classic. Long and technical, with two good rests
content.protection: You can step off at any point.
content.location: Start at Short Man and finish by Screaming Fingers

content.description: Climb the front facing arete of the small rightmost boulder. WITHOUT YOUR HANDS.

This is the portion of the Parking Lot Boulders facing the creek itself.  These are nice clean and vertical faces which remain well shaded throughout the day.  These  faces see a lot of traffic, and are fairly polished.  During the humid summers, the crux of these routes can be just trying to stick your feet on the slightly moist faces.  These faces contain a high concentration of problems in the V0-V3 range making this an excellent location for the beginner to intermediate climber to get a quick burn in.
